resources.string:
Your great Uncle Pineda left very specific instructions. 

To earn his fortune, 
You must spend a night in this old house

The attic is crossed with enormous oak purlins and vertical supporting beams. Pipes and wires will make exploration difficult. Movement is only possible to within a few feet of the edges of the space where the roof angles down to the floor making some parts of the attic too cramped to reach. In the eaves you see evidence of rats and birds.

A simple bathroom with a roll-top bath whose inner surface is chipped and stained. An antique washstand with basin and a jug of water sit on one side. On the other, a cracked ceramic toilet can be seen beneath a cast iron cistern which is bolted high on the wall above.

You enter a large room furnished with an antique four poster bed and a decorative patchwork quilt. A table stands in the corner and on it a jug filled with stagnant water. The wallpaper is drab, peeling in places. There are no pictures on the walls, only square and rectangular pale patches where pictures once hung. An antique Windsor chair is next to the fire; white sheets cover a large antique wardrobe and an antique dresser.

The cellar is dark, dank and creepy. The ceiling is just four feet overhead and consists of thick wooden beams, pipes and electrical wiring filled with spiders and cobwebs. Rusty metal shelves stand on the other side of the room and these are filled with paint tins so rusty they are completely orange and so densely covered with cobwebs that they are almost completely hidden.
A large rectangular dining table stands in the middle of this room, an ornate chandelier hangs above. Cabinets standing around the edges of the room contain photographs and ornaments
You walk into small foyer. Cobwebs fill the dimly lit room. To one side you see a case of broken stairs or you can venture into the hall that will take you deeper into the house.
The hall is covered in torn wall paper and filth. This is not a happy place to be.

The kitchen has been refurbished to appear as it must once have been in the 19th century when the house was first built. The larder is half filled with waxwork food, cans and old tins. Drawers are filled with cutlery and cupboards furnished with pots, pans and dishes.
Top of the stairs. There are doors and a ladder up to the attic.

This bedroom has been furnished to resemble an old fashioned nursery. A crib stands in the corner. Next to it, you see a soft bear and a large wooden dresser with six drawers. A rocking horse, doll house and a box filled with wooden toys also occupy the space. The wall is decorated around its uppermost part with an A,B,C mural. Next to each, picture has been hand painted (A for Apple, B for Bear, C is for Carrot, etc)

The parlor is decorated with 19th century wallpaper, furnishings and ornaments. A crudely made mannequin sits on the couch, his clothing is typical of those worn in the 1800s. The only non-period detail is a broken television which stands on a low table against the inner wall. A portrait hangs over the mantle. There is a piano at the far end of the room and next to the fire is a basket filled with wood.

The house is tall and thin. It is made from large rotting planks. They feel rough; like they have been sandwiched together by disgruntled laborers. Vines cling to the house, thirsting for what little sun can reach them in the shadows. Windows, rattling vigorously from the now howling wind sound as though they are about to fall from their worm eaten frames.
The broken stairs will take you up or down.
